Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Boundary Between Stars and Substellar Objects in the Solar Neighborhood
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Sergio Dieterich is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism of the Carnegie Institution of Washington. Brown dwarfs are objects that never acquired enough mass during their formation to attain the internal temperature and pressure necessary to ignite the sustained nuclear fusion of hydrogen, which is the hallmark of a stellar object. Understanding the boundary between very low mass stars and brown dwarfs has deep implications for the search for life in the Universe. It is likely that life may evolve on planets orbiting stars but it is more difficult for life to evolve on brown dwarf systems due to their constantly changing temperature. Dr. Dieterich studies trends in temperature, radius, and luminosity of objects near the stellar/substellar boundary. His thesis work identified a stellar and a substellar population based on these trends. This work will now be extended to a larger sample of stars, and will explore how chemical compositions for different stars change this boundary. Dr. Dieterich will use his experience as a former middle and high school physical science teacher to facilitate the integration of astronomy in the high school physics curriculum. He will compile an activity book that will serve as a resource for physics teachers who wish to enrich their classes by illustrating physical concepts with examples from astronomy.

Dr. Dieterich will address the following three scientific questions during his fellowship: (1) What is the luminosity function at the stellar/substellar boundary? (2) How does metallicity affect the properties of objects with masses close to the hydrogen burning minimum mass? and (3) How can we use objects with known dynamical masses to create a more robust and detailed Mass-Luminosity Relation at the stellar/substellar boundary? The unique resources of Carnegie's Las Campanas Observatory in Chile are key to answering these questions. Because an accurate distance measurement is essential for establishing luminosity and radius, Dr. Dieterich and collaborators will use the Carnegie Astrometric Planet Search Camera (CAPSCam) on the du Pont 2.5 meter telescope to determine precise trigonometric parallaxes so as to make the study sample volume-complete. Several Las Campanas telescopes will also be used to obtain optical photometry for these very faint objects, which is necessary for calculating bolometric fluxes. Metallicities for the sample will be established through spectroscopic observations done with the Magellan 6.5 meter telescopes. The MagAO adaptive optics system on the Magellan II telescope is one of the only ground based systems capable of obtaining diffraction-limited images in optical wavelengths. This unique capability will be used for the photometric characterization of stars in close binary systems for which dynamical masses are known. The resolved optical photometry will then be used to determine luminosity and effective temperature for these stars, therefore populating the mass-luminosity relation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What are the sizes, masses, and luminosities of the smallest stars in the solar neighborhood and what distinguishes them from their lower mass cousins, the substellar brown dwarfs? The work carried out in this NSF fellowship addressed several aspects of this question. 

This question is an important question in stellar astronomy for several reasons. Unlike stars, brown dwarfs do not produce their own light and are left to cool down after formation, eventually becoming so dim as to be virtually undetectable by current telescopes. However they shine bright while they are young objects (less than about 1 billion years old) and at that phase of their life are difficult to distinguish from stars. Developing methods to distinguish these two populations, the very low mass stars and the young brown dwarfs, provides insight into the overall mass and light budget of the Galaxy and places constraints into how much dark matter may be hiding in the form of cold brown dwarfs. There are also important implications for the question of planetary habitability. Stars are stable objects that provide a constant light flux whereas brown dwarfs are always cooling and becoming dimmer. A planet orbiting a star at the right distance, the so-called habitable zone, could therefore be a stable environment for life to develop and much work has been done in the search for planets around very low mass stars. Planets of a terrestrial composition in the habitable zone of very low mass stars appear to be plentiful. It is therefore important to distinguish if the parent body in these systems are indeed stars as opposed to brown dwarfs, which would make these systems uninhabitable.  Finally, being able to distinguish stars and brown dwarfs from a purely empirical basis provides a test of theoretical models of stellar structure and evolution. These models are the basis for much of our understanding of stellar astrophysics and ensuring their validity places our understanding of the universe on a firmer ground.

In this research the PI and collaborators carried out several projects to characterize objects thought to lie at either side of the stellar-substellar boundary. A sample of about 100 nearby objects was observed using the techniques of photometry and astrometry. Photometry allows astronomers to measure the precise energy fluxes (light) coming from an object in different color regimes. This information is then used to calculate the temperature of the stellar surface and infer its chemical composition. Astrometry is the precise measurements of stellar positions and motions. Astrometry can provide precise values for an object's distance and, in the case of binary systems, the objects' masses. The observational work was carried out at the Carnegie Institution's Las Campanas Observatory in the Chilean Andes using telescopes 1.0,  2.5, and 6.5 meters in size (diameter). 

The results reinforce preliminary findings from the PI's Ph.D. thesis. We confirmed the existence of two observationally distinct populations with a gap in temperature around 2,100 K (3,300 Fahrenheit,  1,800 Celsius).  The hotter population is more numerous, as expected for stars that have a stable temperature versus the cooling brown dwarfs.  This result places the stellar-substellar boundary at about 500 K hotter than expected from theoretical models, indicating that theorists need to revise our understanding stellar structure and evolution. We also measured the mass of a binary brown dwarf system, the Epsilon Indi BC system, by measuring the gravitational interaction of these two objects as they orbit their common center of mass.  We concluded that the components of this binary system have masses of 75.0 and 70.1 Jupiter Masses. The finding is significant because most modern theoretical models predict that brown dwarfs cannot have masses above 73 Jupiter Masses and that at least the most massive component of Epsilon Indi BC should be a star.

When the results of the work carried out in this fellowship, including subtleties not discussed in this summary, are analyzed in a holistic manner a clear picture emerges: the smallest possible stars are more massive, hotter, and brighter than previously thought.

Two high school students participated in this work. They benefited from receiving training in astronomical data analysis and had their first exposure to professional science. One of them was also partially funded as a summer intern with fellowship research funds. An undergraduate student now in astronomy graduate school also participated in the work and had the opportunity to advance her early career through research. In addition to peer reviewed scientific publications a substantial amount of software to facilitate astrometric measurements was developed. This software has been packaged, documented, and is now freely available to the community.
